message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The midline lower abdominal mass extending 2-3 cm above the symphysis suggests posterior urethral valves. The high-grade fever for 3 days suggests a urinary tract infection. Ablation of urethral valves is the most appropriate treatment for this condition. Urethral diverticulectomy is a procedure to treat urethral diverticulum, and endoscopic dextranomer gel injection and vesicostomy are not appropriate for this patient's condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has been diagnosed with a urinary tract infection and has a midline lower abdominal mass, which is suggestive of obstructive uropathy. Ablation of urethral valves is the most appropriate intervention to relieve the obstruction, which will improve urinary flow and help clear the infection. The other options are not appropriate for this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The midline lower abdominal mass that extends above the symphysis suggests the presence of urethral valves, which is a congenital anomaly that can cause urinary tract infections in male newborns. Ablation of the urethral valves is the most appropriate intervention for this patient. Urethral diverticulectomy, endoscopic dextranomer gel injection, and vesicostomy are not appropriate for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is diagnosed with a urinary tract infection which likely resulted from an obstruction caused by urethral valves. Therefore, the most appropriate intervention would be ablation of the urethral valves to relieve the obstruction and prevent further infections. Urethral diverticulectomy, endoscopic dextranomer gel injection, and vesicostomy are not appropriate interventions in this scenario.

The midline lower abdominal mass extending above the symphysis and the symptoms suggest posterior urethral valves, which cause obstruction of urine flow from the bladder to the urethra. Ablation of urethral valves is the most effective intervention for this condition. The other options are not relevant for posterior urethral valves.

Ablation of urethral valves is the most appropriate intervention. Urethral diverticulectomy, endoscopic dextranomer gel injection, and vesicostomy are not appropriate for this condition.

Ablation of urethral valves is the most appropriate intervention in this case as it can improve urine flow and prevent recurrent urinary tract infections. The other options listed are not appropriate for this condition.

Ablation of urethral valves is the best option for this condition. Urethral diverticulectomy, endoscopic dextranomer gel injection, and vesicostomy would not address the underlying problem.

Ablation of the urethral valves is the most appropriate intervention. The other options are not relevant for this condition.
